metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: eddy covariance system of desert station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the desert station eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2022. The site (100.9872° E, 42.1135° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 1054 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.7 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the type of eddy covariance was closed-path (CPEC200).
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions is the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. These instruments provide half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles are collected using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that includes observations of oasis-desert systems for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes observations of oasis-desert systems for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is the dataset available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center. This dataset comprises data from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, collected from 2012 to 2021.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of challenges faced in maintaining ecological stability in arid regions, particularly those involving inland river basins?
Example.Answer: An example of challenges faced in maintaining ecological stability in arid regions involves the ecological environment degradation in inland river basins, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are especially prevalent in areas like the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Definition.Question: What is an eddy covariance system in the context of data collection for oasis–desert systems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a technique used for measuring and analyzing turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane in the atmosphere. It involves the use of instruments that can capture high-frequency data on wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations, which are then processed to obtain half-hourly turbulent flux data, as utilized in oasis–desert systems.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality control procedure' in the context of data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Quality control procedure refers to the systematic process involved in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of collected data. In the context of oasis–desert ecosystems, it involves steps such as data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, ensuring that the datasets are accurate and meet the required standards for use in research and analysis.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of Eddypro software processing techniques influence the quality and accuracy of observed data in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Eddypro software processing techniques influence the quality and accuracy of observed data by applying steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and density correction. These steps ensure data reliability, especially for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, critical for understanding ecological interactions in arid and semiarid regions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges faced in maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems, and how might these challenges impact data collection techniques?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential challenges include the degradation of ecological environments, such as drying rivers and intensifying desertification, which could affect data collection techniques by introducing variability in environmental conditions. These challenges necessitate robust long-term observation systems and careful data processing to maintain data integrity and support sustainable oasis development.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges contribute to sustainable development strategies in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observations provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics, essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This understanding supports ecological stability and socioeconomic development by informing policies and strategies aimed at achieving carbon neutrality and maintaining ecological security in these ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in maintaining the ecological balance between oasis and desert systems during data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in maintaining the ecological balance between oasis and desert systems during data collection in arid and semiarid regions arise from the degradation of the ecological environment, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins along the Silk Road.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to implement long-term observational data collection techniques in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observational data collection techniques in oasis–desert ecosystems are critical to achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which supports ecological security, sustainable development, and helps achieve goals such as carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences for data quality when using a combination of different data processing techniques such as Eddypro software in data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a combination of data processing techniques like Eddypro software can enhance data quality by providing steps like wild point removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and several other adjustments. These steps help ensure accuracy by correcting for potential errors and biases in raw data, thus improving the reliability of the observed flux values.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of various auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters affect the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters can provide a more comprehensive context for interpreting energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations. These additional datasets help in understanding the interactions between different environmental variables and can lead to more accurate insights into ecosystem processes and their responses to environmental changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the potential impact on ecological stability and socio-economic development if long-term observational datasets are used to recognize oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets can significantly enhance the understanding of oasis-desert interactions, which is crucial for maintaining ecological stability. This can lead to informed decision-making that supports sustainable development, helps achieve carbon peaking and neutrality goals, and ensures the ecological security of oasis regions, thus positively impacting both the environment and socio-economic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieving sustainable oasis development, supporting ecological security, and promoting socioeconomic development. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is key to achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals and recognizing the interactions that stabilize ecological and agricultural productivity in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it critical to address the ecological environment degradation in inland river basins when studying oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing ecological environment degradation in inland river basins is critical because these areas are facing crises such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of vegetation, intensification of desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues threaten the ecological stability and sustainability of oasis–desert ecosystems, particularly in regions like the Tarim River basin and others along the Silk Road.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key data processing steps involved in converting raw data from an eddy covariance system into usable flux measurements for desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key data processing steps include outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction (WPL correction). Additionally, flux values undergo quality assessment based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data from periods with instrument errors, rain events, or when more than 10% of original data within 30 minutes is missing, are excluded.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are different types of hydrometeorological data integrated and utilized to support the analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are collected using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. These data, along with groundwater table information, are integrated to provide a comprehensive understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis-desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to ensure the quality and reliability of long-term observational datasets involving energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality and reliability of datasets are ensured through a comprehensive data processing and quality control procedure, which includes data collection, processing, and archiving. The datasets undergo rigorous quality checks, such as removing data with known instrument errors, excluding data around precipitation events, and ensuring no more than 10% of data is missing in any 30-minute period. Additionally, the data are reviewed for consistency and accuracy before being archived and shared.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies and methodologies enable the collection of comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is enabled by the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. These technologies facilitate the observation of radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data.

Enablement.Question: What infrastructural or environmental conditions are necessary to maintain long-term observational datasets in the context of oasis–desert systems within arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems within arid regions requires establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations with consistent data collection capabilities. This involves geographical positioning in key locations such as the middle and lower reaches of river basins, ensuring access to water from cryospheric sources, and providing continuous data collection on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, supplemented by vegetation and soil parameters.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Expectation.Answer: It is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable oasis development and to support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in oasis–desert areas.

Expectation.Question: Why is long-term observation data considered indispensable for understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for obtaining a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This understanding is significant for recognizing the interactions between oases and deserts and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: What are the considerations for ensuring the quality and reliability of data collected using eddy covariance systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The quality and reliability of data collected using eddy covariance systems in arid and semiarid regions can be ensured by implementing rigorous data processing steps such as despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. Additionally, quality assessment of flux values is essential, focusing on atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics. Data should also be screened for instrument errors, precipitation events, and significant data gaps, as described in the field's methodologies.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might researchers face when collecting data in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas, and how can these be mitigated?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers might face challenges such as ecological environment degradation, river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas. These can be mitigated by employing robust and resilient data collection equipment, ensuring regular maintenance and calibration of instruments, and incorporating remote sensing data to complement ground-based observations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how eddy covariance systems are able to measure turbulence-related data so precisely in arid environments.
Assertion.Answer: Eddy covariance systems, like the one mentioned, utilize high-frequency data collection (e.g., 10Hz) to capture fluctuations in wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations, which are then aggregated into averages over set intervals, such as 30 minutes. This method allows for precise calculations of turbulent fluxes even in challenging environments like arid regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from disparate sources in oasis-desert systems can be integrated to study energy and carbon exchange.
Assertion.Answer: Data integration in oasis-desert systems involves combining flux measurements from eddy covariance systems with auxiliary hydrometeorological data, soil and vegetation parameters, and additional environmental data. This integrated approach provides a comprehensive view of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, supporting the understanding of complex interactions within these ecosystems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in maintaining data quality and coverage in oasis–desert ecosystems over long-term observational periods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. Data quality maintenance involves filtering out data during instrument errors, precipitation events, and when data loss exceeds 10% in a 30-minute period.
